templates.content: The percentage of Butylene glycol recommended depends on the product that is being made. For an emulsion or cream, we would suggest 2-5%. And for an oil-free serum, 5-10% usage will provide an elegant glide upon application.
templates.name: How much Butylene glycol do I need? / How do I use it?

templates.content:
Baobab Protein can be used in hair oils with an emulsifier. However, this will make the product take on a fluid cream texture. But with puresilk natural emulsifier, you'll be able to create a very fluid, luxurious cream that's up to 70% in oils.

However, for best results, we suggest sucraclear oil gellant used at 5-15%, as it should be able to thicken the oils to the point where adding up to 5% baobab soluble protein would yield a stable, fluid oil gel.

And for any other products, just make sure to add 1-2% emulsitec plant derived preservative if adding any water-based materials to oils.
templates.name: Can the Baobab Water-Soluble Protein Extract be used in hair oils with an emulsifier?

templates.content:
We started as a dream in a small LA apartment. That dream was to bring eco-friendly and innovative wooden wicks to makers all around the world. We have evolved into a much different business than we were founded as. 

Today, we offer thousands of different products to makers of all types and our dream to revolutionize industry has grown far beyond just wicks.

And as we continue to dream, grow and build together we decided on a new name that encompasses all we've become and all we will continue to become!

templates.content: Butylene glycol is included in formulas for shampoos, conditioner, lotion, sunscreen, anti-aging serums etc, because it adds moisture to the hair and skin. It also works as a solvent, which means it keeps other ingredients such as dyes and pigments from clumping up inside of a solution.

templates.content: Cotton wicks will often "mushroom" or "bloom." Wooden wicks don't - basically, that means that they don't create an ugly black ball on the top of the wick that lingers and smokes after burning for a while. Wooden wicks burn much cleaner, and while they don't get the carbon build-up that needs to be trimmed off of cotton wicks, they will develop a slight amount of ash at the tip of the wick. The ash can be easily broken off when cool before relighting or cut using a wick trimmer.
templates.name: Difference in burning a wooden wick vs a cotton wick

templates.content: When we launched our rebrand, we also launched a new loyalty program that gives us the ability to offer some great new perks, like exclusive discounts on new product launches, higher reward vouchers (up to $1000, to save you time entering codes), a more seamless reward application process at checkout, and for our highest tier, the ability to gift free product with new launches. Lots of good stuff! When we launched the updated loyalty program, our new provider made the mistake of importing the program at $1 = 1 point, and made vouchers equivalent to this, as that is the default in their system. Unfortunately, it took us about 2 weeks to fix this after the program launched and it was brought to our attention. To be super clear, our point valuation didn't change, and your points are still worth the same amount as they were before the rebrand. There was a period where they were worth more than they should have been; customers never have had their point values decreased from how they have historically been. Our intention was absolutely not to mislead our customers in anyway, especially those who are most loyal to our business. We hope this helps provide clarity, and we really appreciate your partnership!

Scientific studies have proven paraffin wax to burn just as cleanly as soy, beeswax, or palm. And the highly refined food-grade nature of our paraffin puts it in the natural category.

templates.content: Tunneling can occur if the wick size isn't optimal for your wax and vessel diameter. If the wick is too small it can't efficiently burn off all of the fuel (wax and fragrance) and generate enough heat to form a good melt pool. To resolve this, try increasing your wick in width (wick up in thickness as well if this doesn't resolve the problem). In some cases, the tunneling can occur when a candle wick consumes too much fuel too quickly. So, if the wick is too large, it will consume the wax extremely fast, causing it to generate too much heat and melt right down the middle of your candle. In this case you'll need to wick down in width (wick down in thickness as well if the problem isn't resolved).
templates.name: How do I resolve tunneling issues with my candles?

templates.content: The Perks levels reset every 12 months from the date that the level was reached if you do not reach the required spend to maintain the threshold. For example, if you are at The Enthusiast ($250 threshold), and earn that level on August 8th, you have until August 8th the following year to reach the qualified spend level amount ($250) again - or your tier will reset to the Enthusiast. When you move up a tier, that erases your previous "earn date" and replaces it with the new date when you reached the newest tier. You have 12 months to maintain that newly acquired tier.

templates.name: How do I redeem/use my points?

templates.content:
It shouldn't as long as you're following the candle burning guidelines. Make sure your wick is trimmed to between 1/8′′ - 3/16′′ / 3.2mm - 4.8mm before lighting. If the wick is too long, the wax won't pull up the wick and it will extinguish. Gently snap off the ash or burnt wood along the top edge of the wick and then light as usual. If when burning the candle for a long period of time you notice the flame height getting too low, it may be necessary to tap off any excess ash or burnt wood along the top of the wick. The flame will then return to its proper optimal height. Be very careful not to let any debris from the wick (or anything else!) fall into the candle. 

Extinguish candle when 1⁄2" / 12.7mm of wax is remaining, and don't burn it for more than 4 hours at one time. Gently blow out the candle, don't extinguish it with water.
templates.name: Will your candles crack?
